seg_1.summary: Summary: Course participation is crucial and primarily occurs through online discussions, constituting 25% of the final grade.  Active involvement in discussions is essential to pass the course, even with strong assignment scores.  Points are awarded for substantive and thoughtful contributions to these discussions.
seg_1.text: Participation is an important component of this course. Online discussion is the primary means for participation. In other words, if you don’t participate in the week’s discussion you have “skipped” class. The discussion constitutes 25% of your coursework. Even if you do stellar work on your assignments, you could fail the course if you are not active the discussions. Keep in mind every point is earned through your actions, and points are only awarded if the contributions are substantive and thoughtful.

seg_2.summary: Summary: To start each week's module, students are asked to reflect on prompts and share their initial views in a discussion post before reviewing the module content. These prompts are designed to initiate engaging conversations among students.
seg_2.text: In order to begin the week’s module, I ask you to think about the prompts and take some time to reflect your views and where you currently stand on particular topics. So without the ability to yet review the week’s module and assigned materials, you will author a message in for the week’s discussion in response to a starter prompt. The prompts vary from week to week, with the aim of sparking an engaged and interesting conversation.

seg_3.summary: Summary:  After posting an initial message, the module unlocks, requiring ongoing dialogue with peers in subgroups for full credit. Active participation in this back-and-forth communication is crucial for successful discussion and module completion.  Lack of engagement in the dialogue phase will negatively impact the grade.
seg_3.text: After you have contributed a starter message, the rest of the module will then be unlocked and I ask that you continue the conversation by engaging in a back-and-forth written dialogue with your peers. Due to the size of the class, this conversation will take place in sub-groups. Please note that this follow-through communication is critical to the conversation’s success, and people who do not participate in this phase of the discussion will not receive full credit.

seg_4.summary: To ensure participation in online discussions, initial messages are due by Thursday night, and follow-up discussions occur from Friday to Sunday.  Missed discussions cannot be made up, and follow-up messages should be spaced throughout the weekend to foster genuine interaction and collaborative learning. The goal is to create knowledge together through meaningful discussion.
seg_4.text: Starter messages must be posted by Thursday night at 11:59 pm EST; follow-through discussion takes place between Friday and Sunday. In the same way that you cannot participate in a face-to-face discussion if you arrive after the session is over, you cannot make up missed discussions. In addition, the follow-through messages should be evenly spaced, not posted at the last minute late Sunday evening. The aim is to have a genuine discussion. The aim is for you (as a group) to create knowledge and to learn from each other.

seg_5.summary: To participate effectively in follow-up discussions, careful reading of the text is necessary. Your initial post should reflect your understanding of the prompts and personal views, while follow-up posts need to demonstrate engagement with and knowledge of the week's materials.  When using personal experiences, ensure they are presented in a reflective and analytical manner.
seg_5.text: It is essential that you go into the follow-up discussions prepared, after doing a careful reading of the text. Your initial post should demonstrate that you have given the prompts (and thus your own views), while your follow-up posts should demonstrate that you are engaged and informed about the week’s materials. While making references to personal experiences can be powerful in generating an interesting conversation, you should discuss these experiences in a reflective, analytical way.

seg_6.summary: Summary: Effective discussion responses should contribute to the conversation by challenging ideas, considering different viewpoints, and prompting deeper understanding. Participants should ask questions, explain their thoughts, and encourage each other to explore concepts more thoroughly. These actions lead to more substantive and thoughtful discussions.
seg_6.text: Your responses should advance the discussion. Challenge one another and push each other to consider other viewpoints and new questions, ask your discussion mates to explain their ideas and take their consideration of the week’s concepts to a deeper level. At a minimum, substantive and thoughtful messages exhibit the following qualities:

seg_7.summary: Summary:  In online discussions, thoughtful and courteous responses are expected, requiring explanations beyond simple agreement or disagreement.  Participants should contribute meaningfully to the conversation by drawing on course materials and personal experiences to justify their input, ensuring relevance to the topic and course concepts.  Avoid superficial responses like "me too" and strive to add value to the discussion.
seg_7.text: • Value: Your responses should be thoughtful and courteous, even if you disagree. Simply stating that you agree or disagree with a statement is insufficient – you must explain why! There's nothing more annoying than clicking on a message link to find that it reads "me too" or "I agree totally." So be sure that your messages add something to the conversation. seg_10.summary: Effective message composition requires conciseness, achieved through careful editing and focusing on a maximum of two main points.  Taking time to craft and format messages enhances clarity and readability, especially by avoiding stream-of-consciousness writing directly in message boards. Starter messages can be longer to establish context, while follow-up messages should be shorter and interactive.
seg_10.text: • Concision: Abraham Lincoln is credited with saying "I'm sorry that this letter is so long. I didn't have time to write a short one." Message composition is part of the learning process, because in editing the message you are also clarifying your thoughts for yourself. Your message should have one main point or thought -- two at the most. Take time to craft your message before you post it, writing a first draft and then editing it down to the most essential components. Format your message in short paragraphs, bullets, headings, etc. to make it easier to read on the screen. Avoid composing directly in the message board because that leads to "stream of conscience" writing. Your starter message may be longer than follow-up messages, because it lays out your thinking. Follow-up messages may be shorter and should be interactive, questioning and building on things that the group has already said.

seg_11.summary: Timeliness is crucial for effective online discussions because posting messages before deadlines allows for richer group interaction and follow-up.  Timely follow-up messages that build upon others' contributions are also important for a good discussion, which involves multiple exchanges and should not be rushed.
seg_11.text: • Timeliness and Follow-Through: The quality of a discussion is directly related to timeliness of posting. When participants post messages before the deadlines, the group has more to work with in the ensuing discussion. Likewise, follow-up messages should be timely and build upon the contributions of others – questioning, looking for connections, reconciling discrepancies, and grappling with ideas. Good discussions involve multiple volleys of communication. As stated earlier, do not wait until the last hour on Sunday to post all of your messages!

seg_8.summary: Summary: Students are encouraged to link course discussions to relevant external resources, such as websites or news clips, and to prior knowledge from other courses.  This approach to learning emphasizes the importance of making connections for deeper understanding.
seg_8.text: website or news clip that’s relevant, or if the discussion resonates with things you’ve learned in other courses, please tell us about it. Making connections is an important part of this approach to learning.

seg_9.summary: Summary: Active participation in the discussion board is encouraged through asking substantive questions that build upon others' ideas and engage with course readings and personal experiences.  Questions can be about others' posts, readings, or broader themes, and participants are welcome to share relevant external resources to enrich the discussion.  This fosters a curious and engaging learning environment.
seg_9.text: • Curiosity and Interest in the Week's Work: Ask substantive questions and build on the ideas of others. Questions can take three forms: a) asking about others’ posts, b) posting a question about the readings that you’d like to discuss, or c) musing about "big" questions that you are still puzzling through. Draw on both course readings and your own experience in answering discussion board questions. Feel free to share any additional readings, URLs, podcasts and videos that will contribute to our discussion.
